Breaking News

Court Grants Restraining Order Against Tabby After 14th Consecutive Evidence Tampering

By Meredith Purl, Esq. • Lead Counsel & Publisher • Feb 11, 2026

In a landmark ruling that legal scholars are calling "the first of its kind and hopefully the last," the Honorable Judge Patricia Orendorff has issued a 50-foot restraining order against Mr. Whiskers, a 9-year-old orange tabby, barring him from the bathroom-office of Purl & Associates for a minimum of 30 days.

The order comes after Mr. Whiskers knocked 347 pages of discovery documents off the filing shelf (the shelf above the toilet) during a critical phone deposition with opposing counsel last Thursday. This marks the 14th such incident since Purl & Associates opened its doors — and shower curtain — in 2019.

"I watched him make eye contact with me, extend one paw, and sweep the entire Henrickson estate plan into the bathwater. He knew what he was doing." — Meredith Purl, Esq., in her filed motion

The motion, filed while Meredith was simultaneously conducting a client intake call and working Row 47 of a cable-knit cardigan, details a pattern of "deliberate, calculated, and frankly spiteful" interference with legal proceedings. Exhibit A includes a waterlogged copy of a prenuptial agreement with a single paw print in the signature line.

Mr. Whiskers' court-appointed representative, a Labrador named Doug who passed the bar in a dream Meredith had, argued that the tabby was "merely exercising his constitutional right to knock things off surfaces." The argument was not well-received.

"He has no constitutional rights," Judge Orendorff noted. "He is a cat."

Mr. Whiskers is expected to relocate to the hallway, where he will continue to stare at the closed bathroom door for 6 to 11 hours per day. His co-conspirator, Duchess (a tortoiseshell, 4), remains under investigation for a separate incident involving a ball of merino wool and a notarized power of attorney.

Purl & Associates has announced it will install a baby gate. This is the third baby gate. The other two were knocked off their mounts.

Opinion

I Knit During Depositions and I Will Not Apologize

Meredith Purl, Esq. • Editorial

The American Bar Association has no official stance on knitting during legal proceedings. I checked. Three times. They stopped returning my calls, which I interpret as tacit approval.

Since 2019, I have completed 43 scarves, 12 cardigans, 7 blankets, and one very long sock during depositions, client meetings, and settlement negotiations. My win rate during knitting sessions is 74%. Without knitting, it drops to 31%. The yarn speaks through me.

Last Tuesday, I finished a particularly difficult yoke pattern at the exact moment opposing counsel crumbled and accepted our settlement offer of $47,500. Coincidence? The yarn knows it isn't.

To the unnamed judge who asked me to "put the needles down" during oral arguments: no. They are size 7 bamboo circulars and they are load-bearing to my legal strategy. I will, however, switch to wooden needles if the clicking is truly distracting. I am not unreasonable.

Ask the Tub

Legal advice from Meredith Purl, Esq., while she soaks. This column is for entertainment purposes only and also actual legal advice. Both.

"My landlord says I can't run a business from my apartment. Can they do that?" +

Depends on your lease. Mine says "no commercial activity" but it doesn't define "commercial" and it doesn't mention bathtubs specifically. I've been operating on the legal theory that a bathtub is not a commercial space — it's a personal hygiene space that happens to contain a law practice. My landlord, Jerry, has stopped arguing with me about this. I interpret his silence as agreement. Jerry, if you're reading this: the rent check is on the bath caddy. Send someone tall to get it. The caddy is high up now because of the cats.

— Meredith Purl, Esq., from the Tub, 103°F
"Can I sue my cat?" +

Technically, no. Legally, cats lack the standing to be defendants in civil court. Trust me, I've tried. Fourteen times. However, I have pioneered what I call the "Indirect Consequences Doctrine," which holds that if a cat's actions directly result in financial loss (e.g., knocking a laptop worth $1,299 into a bathtub), the cat's owner — in my case, also me — can file a claim against their own homeowner's insurance. I have done this four times. My premiums are $347/month now. The insurance company sends me a Christmas card every year that just says "Please stop."

— Meredith Purl, Esq., from the Tub, 101°F
"Is a wet signature still legally binding if it got wet from bathwater?" +

This is actually my area of expertise. I've written a 47-page brief on this (now laminated). Short answer: yes, a signature remains valid regardless of the source of moisture. The law does not distinguish between "signed in the rain," "signed near a pool," and "signed by a woman in a clawfoot tub while a cat watched with what can only be described as malice." The signature is the intent. The water is incidental. I have case law on this. Well — I had case law on this. It's in the toilet now. Thanks, Mr. Whiskers.

— Meredith Purl, Esq., from the Tub, 106°F (too hot today)
"How do I find a good lawyer?" +

Look for three things: competence, compassion, and adequate water temperature. Most lawyers only offer the first two. At Purl & Associates, I offer all three, plus the soothing ambient sound of running water during every consultation. My win rate in cases argued above 102°F is 74%. Below 100°F, it drops significantly. I don't take cold-bath cases. I don't believe in them.

— Meredith Purl, Esq., from the Tub, 104°F (perfect)
"My neighbor's tree is dropping leaves into my yard. Legal options?" +

You may trim any branches that extend over your property line. Beyond that, I'd recommend what I call the "Fernsby Approach" — named after my client Gerald, who came to me with the same issue but about a fence. We settled for $4,200 and Gerald is very happy. The trick is specificity. Don't just say "the tree is annoying." Document every leaf. Photograph them. Name them, if possible. I named a piece of evidence once. His name was Exhibit Gregory. Mr. Whiskers ate him.

— Meredith Purl, Esq., from the Tub, 102°F

This Week's Pattern: The Non-Disclosure Scarf

A knitting pattern that is also a legally binding non-disclosure agreement. By wearing this scarf, the recipient agrees to the terms knitted herein.

MATERIALS: 2 skeins worsted weight (color: Confidential Burgundy) NEEDLES: US 7 bamboo circulars (the same ones I use in court) GAUGE: 18 st x 24 rows = 4" (gauge may vary if knitting in water) CO 42 sts. Rows 1-6: *K2, P2* across (this establishes the "WHEREAS" clause) Row 7: K across (the "Party of the First Part" row) Row 8: P across (the "Party of the Second Part" row) Rows 9-14: Cable pattern C6F (this is the binding arbitration section) Row 15: BO 4 sts, K to end (the limitation of liability) Rows 16-200: Repeat Rows 7-15 (the terms & conditions) Final row: BO all sts. Weave in ends. File with the county clerk. NOTE: If Mr. Whiskers unravels this scarf, the NDA is void and all parties are released from their obligations. This has happened twice.

Vol. VII, No. 20: We incorrectly identified Duchess as "the good cat." We have no good cats. The description was aspirational.

Vol. VII, No. 19: The crossword puzzle answer for 14-Down ("Five-letter word for 'legal professional'") was printed as "PURRL." The correct answer is "LAWYER." We stand by "PURRL."

Vol. VII, No. 18: We stated that Meredith Purl placed "2nd at the Reno Invitational." She placed 3rd. The 2nd-place finisher was a woman named Brenda who Meredith does not wish to discuss. We will not be printing corrections about Brenda going forward.

Vol. VII, No. 17: The "Legal Horoscope" column predicted that Virgos would "win a major settlement this week." No Virgos contacted our firm. We are concerned about the Virgos and would like to hear from them.

Vol. VII, No. 15: Due to a printing error caused by Mr. Whiskers walking across the keyboard, page 3 of Issue No. 15 read, in its entirety: "hhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhjjjjjjjjjjkkkkkkkkkk." We did not notice for two weeks. Neither did our readers, apparently.

General correction: Several past issues contained the phrase "Purl & Associates." There are no associates. It's just me. And the cats. The cats are not associates. They are, at best, hostile witnesses.
